author: ankur2534
content: Is this a real economic attack? Sounds interesting.... If miners 51% attack the network by massively increasing gaslimit, they will make more money from MINER_TIP but lose money from uncles and node costs. But that also assumes all miners have equal miner tip requirements and also increase their miner tip requirements by the same amount. We could see a situation where miners with less efficient setups (higher uncle rates) lose more money than others and decide to defect and lower gaslimit.

author: ankur2534
content: So I'm not sure it ends up being very different from the current game theory around miner block gaslimit settings?

author: elayne_malachite
content: It's not easy to predict how much miners can raise the gas limit since the demand elasticity of the miner tips are extremely high. It is sufficient to say, that doubling or tripling the gas limit would be a not good  thing for Ethereum's long term health. Especially given that larger gas limits reduces the base-fee, which can allow use-cases for Ethereum which have been priced out to become viable again as well as promoting the usage of DeFi by smaller users, which would be good for the short-term health of Ethereum. A bit like climate change.

author: sky.cactus
content: If miners increase the gas limit to dangerous amounts we can hard fork that away from them.  It isn't an attack that we have no defense against.

author: elayne_malachite
content: The issue is that this is just the natural outcome of a base-fee burn with a minimal, roughly flat miner tip because that changes miner incentives to be in favor of state-growth. This is part of the reason why l-smoothing is the better option for what to do with the base-fee since we aren't changing the miner incentives with respect to state-growth.

author: sky.cactus
content: The *correct* solution to miner's inappropriately moving the gas limit up is to take gas limit controls away from miners.  Generally speaking, bribing people to do the right thing is a poor solution to a problem and should not be preferred to a more direct solution like taking power away from the people who abuse it.

author: elayne_malachite
content: The correct solution is to avoid creating the economic incentive for bad behavior in the first place. Especially if it's shown that there is an alternate proposal with substantially similar security and feasibility. Even more so, when it creates this much contention in the community.

author: sky.cactus
content: Gas limit under control of miners is an optimistic optimization.  If the miners behave, it is slightly better to give them control of the gas limit.  If they misbehave, we can take it away quite easily in the next hard fork.  So far, they have behaved and we have benefited from that optimization.

author: sky.cactus
content: Often times in mechanism design you'll end up with solutions that would be better in some way if people just so happen to behave well, and if they misbehaved the negative effects are limited/constrained.  In such cases, there can be great value in optimistically hoping for altruism and seeing you happen to get it.

author: timbeiko
content: <@!494908382889639977> miners decide to raise the block limit to, say, 50m, post-1559. If everyone else thinks this is bad, you can release a version of geth/open ehtereum/etc. which says "we don't consider blocks with a gas limit >20m to be valid". Because this is a strict subset of the validity conditions of the nodes miners run, we don't need them to update (given they _can_ still produce <=20m blocks). Everyone else can just "refuse to acknoledge" their big blocks are valid.
